item.title: Google Owes $314 Million for Misusing Android Cell Phone Data
item.description: Google was told by a California jury to pay $314 million over claims that it illegally used Android users’ cellular data to collect information without their knowledge.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: The Android logo appears on the screen of a smartphone in Reno, United States, on November 29, 2024.

item.title: Binance to Keep Hundreds of Staff in Singapore Despite Crackdown
item.description: The world’s largest digital-assets exchange Binance plans to keep hundreds of remote workers in Singapore, despite a crackdown on unlicensed crypto outfits in the city-state.
item.dc:creator: Suvashree Ghosh

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians on the Jubilee Bridge in front of buildings in the central business district of Singapore, on Saturday, May 17, 2025. Singapore is scheduled to release gross domestic product (GDP) figures on May 22.

item.title: Columbia University Applicant Personal Data Stolen by Hacker
item.description: Personal information about Columbia University students and applicants — including whether they were accepted or rejected by the school — has been stolen, according to a Bloomberg News review of data provided by a person who claimed to have hacked the school in June.
item.dc:creator: Cameron Fozi

media:content.media:description: Graduates during a Columbia University commencement ceremony in New York.

item.title: Figma Files for US IPO Showing Gains in Revenue, Profit
item.description: Design software business Figma Inc. filed Tuesday for what could be one of the year’s biggest initial public offerings.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes, Katie Roof

media:content.media:description: The Figma logo on a smartphone. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: Thoma Bravo Is in Talks to Acquire Verint Systems
item.description: Buyout firm Thoma Bravo is in talks to acquire Verint Systems Inc., a maker of call center software, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould

media:content.media:description: Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

item.title: Mexico Congress Backs Bill to Overhaul Telecoms Regulations
item.description: Mexico’s lower house approved the general text of a watered-down bill to overhaul telecommunications regulations, after the proposal’s initial draft provoked objections that the government was seeking to censor critical media.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum

item.title: Bezos Unloads $737 Million of Amazon Stock in Year’s First Sale
item.description: Jeff Bezos sold 3.3 million Amazon.com Inc. shares in recent days, netting $736.7 million.
item.dc:creator: Biz Carson

media:content.media:description: Amazon's founder Jeff Bezos and spouse Lauren Sanchez Bezos leave the Aman Hotel on the third day of their wedding festivities, in Venice on June 28, 2025. (Photo by Marco BERTORELLO / AFP) (Photo by MARCO BERTORELLO/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Struggling Semiconductor Firm Wolfspeed Files for Bankruptcy
item.description: Wolfspeed Inc., a chipmaker caught in President Donald Trump’s push to reshape Biden-era tech subsidies, filed bankruptcy to enact a creditor-backed plan to slash $4.6 billion in debt.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Randles, Steven Church

media:content.media:description: A Wolfspeed wafer Photographer: Boris Roessler/picture alliance/Getty Images

item.title: Hardware Startup Nothing Reveals Its Most Avant-Garde Smartphone Yet
item.description: The five-year-old company, known for its bold designs, unveiled the Phone 3 and a pair of similarly quirky headphones.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Kelly, Mark Gurman, Chris Welch

media:content.media:description: Nothing's Phone 3.

item.title: Donald Trump, Elon Musk Fallout Deepens | Bloomberg Tech 7/1/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss the clashes between President Donald Trump and Elon Musk. Plus, the Tesla CEO will oversee sales in Europe and the US as investors brace for disappointing delivery numbers in the second quarter. And, Apple considers using outside AI from Anthropic or OpenAI to power Siri. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Huawei Bid to Dismiss US Trade Sanction Case Rejected by Judge
item.description: Huawei Technologies Co. must face a criminal trial next year in New York after a federal judge refused a request by the Chinese wireless equipment maker to dismiss more than a dozen charges, including racketeering, trade secret theft and violating US sanctions on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado

media:content.media:description: A Huawei Technologies Co. store in Shanghai.

item.title: Chipmakers Win Bigger Tax Credit Under Bill Passed by Senate
item.description: Sweeping tax legislation passed by the Senate Tuesday would make it cheaper for semiconductor manufacturers to build plants in the US, delivering a win to chipmakers and boosting US efforts to expand the industry domestically.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz, Mackenzie Hawkins

media:content.media:description: Construction at the site of Micron Technology new semiconductor factory in Boise, Idaho.

item.title: X Will Deploy AI to Write Community Notes, Expand Fact-Checking
item.description: Elon Musk’s X will start to publish Community Notes written by artificial intelligence agents, a move to increase the speed of the social network’s fact-checking product and expand it to reach more people.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

item.title: Robotics Startup Raises $105 Million Seed From US, China VCs
item.description: Genesis AI, a startup working on software for robots, has raised $105 million in a funding round with both US and Chinese backers — a rarity in an industry split along geopolitical lines.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot

media:content.media:description: A humanoid robot at the Microsoft Corp. booth at the Hannover Messe 2025 trade fair in Hannover, Germany, on Monday, March 31, 2025. German inflation slowed more than anticipated in March, nearing the European Central Bank's 2% target as officials ponder whether to lower interest rates again at their next meeting or pause. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: E-Commerce Firm Jumia Draws Takeover Interest From Axian
item.description: Jumia Technologies AG, the biggest e-commerce company in Africa, has drawn takeover interest from telecommunications company Axian Telecom, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Loni Prinsloo

media:content.media:description: A worker scans inventory inside a Jumia Technologies AG distribution warehouse in Lagos, Nigeria, on Friday, April 12, 2019. Jumia shares soared by 75 percent on their first day of trading in New York, as investors rushed to buy into the companys plans to extend online shopping services across Africa.

item.title: Netflix’s Lofty Valuation Has Even Bullish Investors Nervous
item.description: Netflix Inc. investors face a dilemma: Continue to bet on a stock that has delivered best-in-class returns over the past year or reconsider shares that increasingly look like they’re priced for perfection.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica

item.title: ECB Keeps Hold of Worldline Bonds Amid Alleged Fraud Reports
item.description: The European Central Bank held on to two bonds of embattled payments company Worldline SA while prices slumped following news reports alleging that the company covered up fraud by some of its customers.
item.dc:creator: Tasos Vossos

media:content.media:description: The Worldline SA office building in Paris. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: Microsoft Signs Deal to Power Premier League’s AI Tools
item.description: Microsoft Corp. has signed a cloud computing deal with the Premier League, a pact that will let the software company tout its AI technology to a captive audience of sports fans.
item.dc:creator: Matt Day

media:content.media:description: Liverpool players celebrate winning the Premier League.

item.title: Ninja Becomes Unicorn in Saudi After Riyad Capital-Led Funding Round
item.description: Saudi Arabia-based quick delivery firm Ninja has become the kingdom’s newest tech unicorn after raising around $250 million from local investors, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Parasie

media:content.media:description: The Ninja website

item.title: Robinhood's CEO on the Plan to Tokenize Everything
item.description: Here comes 24-hour stock trading.
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Robinhood Markets CEO Vlad Tenev

item.title: M&S Expects Cyberattack Impact to Be Over By August, CEO Says
item.description: Marks and Spencer Group Plc expects its online services to be fully restored in the next four weeks as it continues to recover from April’s cyberattack, Chief Executive Officer Stuart Machin said.
item.dc:creator: Elliot Burrin

media:content.media:description: A notice on the M&S website following a cyber attack in May.

item.title: Simulation of Crashed Air India Jet Puts Focus on Technical Flaw
item.description: More than two weeks after the deadly crash of an Air India plane that killed all but one of the 242 people on board, investigators and the airline are studying possible dual engine failure as a scenario that prevented the Boeing Co. 787 jet from staying airborne.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Mishra

media:content.media:description: Aircraft debris at the crash site of Air India Ltd. flight AI171 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India, on Thursday, June 12, 2025.

item.title: Senate Votes 99-1 to Strip AI Provision From Trump’s Tax Bill
item.description: The Senate killed a controversial effort to prevent US states from regulating artificial intelligence, marking a loss for the Silicon Valley leaders and White House officials who pushed the measure.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Oma Seddiq, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Tennessee Senator Marsha Blackburn at the US Capitol on June 30. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico/AP Photo

item.title: Amazon Aims for ‘Fast and Faster’ in India as Quick Commerce Surges
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Sankalp Phartiyal looks at the task ahead for Amazon as it tries to keep pace with local upstarts offering far faster delivery in the hotly competitive Indian market.
item.dc:creator: Sankalp Phartiyal

media:content.media:description: A delivery rider driving a Mahindra Treo Zor electric vehicle waits at a pedestrian crossing while fulfilling orders in Noida, Uttar Pradesh, India, on Monday, June 28, 2021. BigBasket and online giants Amazon.com Inc. and Flipkart -- who could hold the key to getting more gas-guzzlers off India's roads -- are struggling to source enough vehicles to meet ambitious targets to electrify their delivery fleets.

item.title: Deutsche Bank Aims to Launch Crypto Custody Service in 2026
item.description: Deutsche Bank AG plans to launch its digital assets custody service next year and has enlisted crypto exchange Bitpanda’s technology unit to help build the offering, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Arno Schuetze, Anna Irrera

media:content.media:description: A Deutsche Bank AG branch in Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Blackout, Fire Warnings Flashed From Home Sensors Hours Before Crises
item.description: Leveraging home sensors and AI, Whisker Labs has developed new ways to rapidly track electricity flows to detect grid faults — leaving some power providers trailing
item.dc:creator: Naureen S Malik, Leonardo Nicoletti

media:content.media:description: Ting devices used for testing are seen during at Whisker Labs' corporate offices on February 5, 2025 in Germantown, Maryland. Whisker Labs has developed a device, Ting, that collects data about the power coming into consumer’s homes and can detect arcing both inside the house as well as on the larger grid. Photographer: Pete Kiehart/Pete Kiehart

item.title: Peter Thiel-Backed Fintech Investor Sells $70 Million Stake in Wise
item.description: Valar Ventures, a fintech fund backed by Peter Thiel, sold a nearly £50 million ($68.8 million) stake in Wise Plc, exiting a position it built as one of the international payments firm’s early investors.
item.dc:creator: Charles Capel

media:content.media:description: The Wise Plc logo.

item.title: SAP Wins Early US Court Decision in Celonis Antitrust Case
item.description: SAP SE won an early round in a lawsuit filed in the US by one of Europe’s most valuable startups accusing the German technology giant of illegally wielding its market power.
item.dc:creator: Christina Kyriasoglou

media:content.media:description: The SAP SE campus in Walldorf, Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Chip-Design Firm SkyeChip Is Close to a Malaysian IPO, CEO Says
item.description: Malaysian semiconductor designer SkyeChip Sdn. is “close” to an initial public offering after posting consecutive years of revenue and profit growth, said Chief Executive Officer Fong Swee Kiang.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Silicon wafer.

item.title: Korea Wealth Fund to Boost Bets on AI Startups, Eyes China Tech
item.description: South Korea’s sovereign wealth fund plans to increase allocations to tech startups and venture capital funds as part of its broader push to deepen exposure to artificial intelligence and other disruptive technologies.
item.dc:creator: David Ingles, Yoolim Lee
